fate: U.S. five-and-dime chain wound down in 1997; parent reoriented around athletic retail (Foot Locker) and later dropped the Woolworth name.
summary: Iconic American five-and-dime founded in 1879. The U.S. stores were closed in 1997 as the company pivoted to its successful Foot Locker banner; international Woolworth successors persisted under separate ownership.
overview_md:
**Woolworth (US)** popularized the American five-and-dime: compact variety stores that sold everyday goods at fixed low prices and often included busy lunch counters. Frank W. Woolworth opened his first successful store in **1879**, then expanded through a web of affiliated chains that merged in **1912** as the F. W. Woolworth Company. The brand became a Main Street staple and corporate symbol—complete with the neo-Gothic **Woolworth Building** (1913) in New York City—while rolling out thousands of stores across the U.S.

Late-20th-century shifts undermined the model. Discount big-box chains, malls, and category killers chipped away at traffic and margins, and Woolworth’s attempts at modernization were uneven. One bright spot was athletic footwear: banners like **Foot Locker** delivered growth and brand relevance. In **1997** the company shuttered remaining U.S. Woolworth stores to focus on its athletic specialty business. The parent later renamed itself **Venator Group** and, in **2001**, **Foot Locker, Inc.** International “Woolworths” entities followed their own paths, with some continuing as distinct companies in Europe and elsewhere.

Today, Woolworth is remembered for pioneering mass-market retail and for the lunch counters that figured in American social history—while its lasting commercial legacy lives on through Foot Locker’s global chain.

timeline.text: First successful five-and-dime opens; the Woolworth retail formula begins to scale.
F. W. Woolworth Company is formed via merger of affiliated five-and-dime chains.
Woolworth Building opens in New York City as company headquarters.
Woolworth lunch counter sit-ins highlight the chain’s place in U.S. civil-rights history.
Company announces closure of remaining U.S. Woolworth stores and pivots toward Foot Locker; parent soon adopts Venator, then Foot Locker, Inc. (2001).

sources.label: The New York Times – Woolworth to Close Remaining Stores in U.S. (July 18, 1997)
Wikipedia – Foot Locker (corporate lineage from Woolworth/Venator)
